segment.a: The sea bed was scoured with powerful nets and there was tremendous excitement on board when a chest was raised from the bottom.

segment.tip: 船员们开始认为沉船找着了，但海底沉箱内的物品证明他们弄错了。
segment.a: Though the crew were at first under the impression that the lost ship had been found, the contents of the chest proved them wrong.

segment.tip: 事实上他们发现的是另一艘沉没多年的船。
segment.a: What they had in fact found was a ship which had been sunk many years before.

segment.tip: 木箱内装有水手艾伦·菲尔丁的私人财物，
segment.a: The chest contained the personal belongings of a seaman, Alan Fielding.

segment.tip: 其中有书籍、衣服、照片以及水手收到的妻子的来信。
segment.a: There were books, clothing and photographs, together with letters which the seaman had once received from his wife.

segment.tip: “埃尔科”号船长命令船员尽量从沉船中打捞物品，
segment.a: The captain of the Elkor ordered his men to salvage as much as possible from the wreck.

segment.tip: 但没发现什么值钱的东西，不过打捞出来的众多的物品还是引起了大家极大的兴趣。
segment.a: Nothing of value was found, but the numerous items which were brought to the surface proved to be of great interest.

segment.tip: 从捞起的一门大炮来看，船长认为那艘船一定是艘巡洋舰。
segment.a: From a heavy gun that was raised, the captain realized that the ship must have been a cruiser.

segment.tip: 另一只海底沉箱中装的是船上一位军官的财物，其中有-一封写于1943年3月14日的信，但没有写完。
segment.a: In another chest, which contained the belongings of a ship's officer, there was an unfinished letter which had been written on March 14th, 1943.

segment.tip: 从这封信中船长了解到沉船船名是“卡伦”号。
segment.a: The captain learnt from the letter that the name of the lost ship was the Karen.

segment.tip: 打捞到的东西中最有价值的是船上的航海日志，其中有一部分仍然清晰可读。
segment.a: The most valuable find of all was the ship's log book, parts of which it was still possible to read.

segment.tip: 据此，船长可以将所有的那些已经搞清的材料拼凑起来。
segment.a: From this the captain was able to piece together all the information that had come to light.

segment.tip: “卡伦”号当年在为其他船只护航驶往俄国途中突然遭到敌方潜水艇鱼雷的袭击。
segment.a: The Karen had been sailing in a convoy to Russia when she was torpedoed by an enemy submarine.

segment.tip: 这一说法在“埃尔科”号返航后得到国防部一位海军官员的证实。
segment.a: This was later confirmed by naval official at the Ministry of Defiance after the Elkor had returned home.

segment.tip: 那次打捞到的所有物品均被送往军事博物馆。
segment.a: All the items that were found were sent to the War Museum.

segment.tip: 我们大家都有过事事不顺心的日子。
segment.a: We have all experienced days when everything goes wrong.

segment.tip: 一天开始时，可能还不错，但突然间似乎一切都失去了控制。
segment.a: A day may begin well enough, but suddenly everything seems to get out of control.

segment.tip: 情况经常是这样的，许许多多的事情都偏偏赶在同一时刻出问题，
segment.a: What invariably happens is that a great number of things choose to go wrong at precisely the same moment.

segment.tip: 好像是一件无关紧要的小事引起了一连串的连锁反应。
segment.a: It is as if a single unimportant event set up a chain of reactions.

segment.tip: 假设你在做饭，同时又在照看孩子。
segment.a: Let us suppose that you are preparing a meal and keeping an eye on the baby at the same time.

segment.tip: 这时电话铃响了。它预示着一连串意想不到的灾难的来临。
segment.a: The telephone rings and this marks the prelude to an unforeseen series of catastrophes.

segment.tip: 就在你接电话时，孩子把桌布从桌子上扯下来，将家中最好的陶瓷餐具半数摔碎，同时也弄伤了他自己。
segment.a: While you are on the phone, the baby pulls the tablecloth off the table, smashing half your best crockery and cutting himself in the process.

segment.tip: 你急急忙忙挂上电话，赶去照看孩子和餐具。
segment.a: You hang up hurriedly and attend to baby, crockery, etc.

segment.tip: 这时，饭又烧糊了。
segment.a: Meanwhile, the meal gets burnt.

segment.tip: 好像这一切还不足以使你急得掉泪，你的丈夫接着回来了，事先没打招呼就带来3个客人吃饭。
segment.a: As if this were not enough to reduce you to tears, your husband arrives, unexpectedly bringing three guests to dinner.

segment.tip: 就像许多人最近在悉尼郊区帕拉马塔发现的那样，有时乱子会闹得很大。
segment.a: Things can go wrong on a big scale, as a number of people recently discovered in Parramatta, a suburb of Sydney.

segment.tip: 一天傍晚交通最拥挤时，一辆汽车撞上前面一辆汽车，两个司机争吵起来。
segment.a: During the rush hour one evening two cars collided and both drivers began to argue.

segment.tip: 紧跟其后的一辆车上的司机碰巧是个初学者，
segment.a: The woman immediately behind the two cars happened to be a learner.

segment.tip: 她一惊之下突然把车停了下来。
segment.a: She suddenly got into a panic and stopped her car.

segment.tip: 她这一停使得跟在后头的司机也来个急刹车。
segment.a: This made the driver following her brake hard.

segment.tip: 司机妻子正坐在他身边，手里托着块大蛋糕。
segment.a: His wife was sitting beside him holding a large cake.

segment.tip: 她往前一冲，蛋糕从挡风玻璃飞了出去掉到马路上。 \n 直译： 当她被抛向前时，蛋糕直接穿过了挡风玻璃，落在了路上。
segment.a: As she was thrown forward, the cake went right through the windscreen and landed on the road.

segment.tip: 此时，一辆卡车正好从后边开到那辆汽车边上，司机看见一块蛋糕从天而降，紧急刹车。 。 \n 直译： 看到一个蛋糕在空中飞过，一个正靠近汽车的卡车司机突然停了下来。
segment.a: Seeing a cake flying through the air, a lorry driver who was drawing up alongside the car, pulled up all of a sudden.

segment.tip: 卡车上装着空啤酒瓶。成百只瓶子顺势从卡车后面滑出车外落在马路上。
segment.a: The lorry was loaded with empty beer bottles and hundreds of them slid off the back of the vehicle and on to the road.

segment.tip: 这又引起一场唇枪舌剑的争吵。
segment.a: This led to yet another angry argument.

segment.tip: 与此同时，后面的车辆排成了长龙，
segment.a: Meanwhile, the traffic piled up behind.

segment.tip: 警察花了将近一个小时才使车辆又开起来。
segment.a: It took the police nearly an hour to get the traffic on the move again.

segment.tip: 在这段时间里，卡车司机不得不清扫那几百只破瓶子。
segment.a: In the meantime, the lorry driver had to sweep up hundreds of broken bottles.

segment.tip: 只有两只野狗从这一片混乱中得到好处，它们贪婪地吃掉了剩下的蛋糕。
segment.a: Only two stray dogs benefited from all this confusion, for they greedily devoured what was left of the cake.

segment.tip: 这就是事事不顺心的那么一天！
segment.a: It was just one of those days!

segment.tip: 古玩店对许多人来说有一种特殊的魅力。
segment.a: Antique shops exert a peculiar fascination on a great many people.

segment.tip: 高档一点的古玩店为了防尘，把文物漂亮地陈列在玻璃柜子里，那里往往令人望而却步。
segment.a: The more expensive kind of antique shop where rare objects are beautifully displayed in glass cases to keep them free from dust is usually a forbidding place.

segment.tip: 而对不太装腔作势的古玩店，无论是谁都不用壮着胆子才敢往里进。
segment.a: But no one has to muster up courage to enter a less pretentious antique shop.

segment.tip: 人们还常常有希望在发霉、阴暗、杂乱无章、迷宫般的店堂里，从杂乱地摆放在地面上的、一堆堆各式各样的破烂货里找到一件稀世珍品。
segment.a: There is always hope that in its labyrinth of musty, dark, disordered rooms a real rarity will be found amongst the piles of assorted junk that little the floors.

segment.tip: 无论是谁都不会一下子就发现一件珍品。
segment.a: No one discovers a rarity by chance.

segment.tip: 一个到处找便宜的人必须具有耐心，而且最重要的是看到珍品时要有鉴别珍品的能力。
segment.a: A truly dedicated bargain hunter must have patience, and above all, the ability to recognize the worth of something when he sees it.

segment.tip: 要做到这一点，他至少要像古董商一样懂行。
segment.a: To do this, he must be at least as knowledgeable as the dealer.

segment.tip: 他必须像一个专心致志进行探索的科学家那样抱有这样的希望，即终有一天，他的努力会取得丰硕的成果。
segment.a: Like a scientist bent on making a discovery, he must cherish the hope that one day he will be amply rewarded.

segment.tip: 我的老朋友弗兰克.哈利戴正是这样一个人。
segment.a: My old friend, Frank Halliday, is just such a person.

segment.tip: 他多次向我详细讲他如何只花50英镑便买到一位名家的杰作。
segment.a: He has often described to me how he picked up a masterpiece for a mere ￡50.

segment.tip: 一个星期六的上午，弗兰克去了我家附近的一家古玩店。
segment.a: One Saturday morning, Frank visited an antique shop in my neighbourhood.

segment.tip: 由于他从未去过那儿，结果他发现许多有趣的东西。
segment.a: As he had never been there before, he found a great deal to interest him.

segment.tip: 上午很快过去了，弗兰克正准备离去，突然看见地板上放着一只体积很大的货箱。
segment.a: The morning passed rapidly and Frank was about to leave when he noticed a large packing case lying on the floor.

segment.tip: 古董商告诉他那只货箱刚到不久，但他嫌麻烦不想把它打开。
segment.a: The dealer told him that it had just come in but that he could not be bothered to open it.

segment.tip: 经弗兰克恳求，古董商才勉强把货箱撬开了。
segment.a: Frank begged him to do so and the dealer reluctantly prised it open.

segment.tip: 箱内东西令人失望。
segment.a: The contents were disappointing.

segment.tip: 除了一柄式样别致、雕有花纹的匕首外，货箱内装满陶器，而且大部分都已破碎裂。
segment.a: Apart from an interesting-looking carved dagger, the box was full of crockery, much of it broken.

segment.tip: 弗兰克轻轻地把陶器拿出箱子，突然发现在箱底有一幅微型画，
segment.a: Frank gently lifted the crockery out of the box an suddenly noticed a miniature painting at the bottom of the packing case.

segment.tip: 画面构图与纸条使他想起一幅他所熟悉的意大利画，于是他决定将画买了下来。
segment.a: As its composition and line reminded him of an Italian painting he knew well, he decided to buy it.

segment.tip: 古董商漫不经心看了一眼那幅画，告诉弗兰克那画值50英镑。
segment.a: Glancing at it briefly, the dealer told him that it was worth ￡50.

segment.tip: 弗兰克几乎无法掩饰自己兴奋的心情，因为他明白自己发现了一件珍品。
segment.a: Frank could hardly conceal his excitement, for he knew that he had made a real discovery.

segment.tip: 那幅不大的画原来是柯勒乔的一幅未被发现的杰作，价值几十万英镑。
segment.a: The tiny painting proved to be an unknown masterpiece by Correggio and was worth hundreds of thousands of pounds.

segment.tip: “正义”这个词常常是同法庭连在一起的。
segment.a: The word justice is usually associated with courts of law.

segment.tip: 当某人被证据确凿地证明无罪的时候，我们也许会说正义得到了伸张。
segment.a: We might say that justice has been done when a man's innocence or guilt has been proved beyond doubt.

segment.tip: 正义是复杂的法律机器组成部分。
segment.a: Justice is part of the complex machinery of the law.

segment.tip: 那些寻求正义的人走的是一条崎岖的道路，从来没有把握他们最终将到正义。
segment.a: Those who seek it undertake an arduous journey and can never be sure that they will find it.

segment.tip: 法官无论如何聪明与有名，毕竟也是人，也会出差错的。
segment.a: Judges, however wise or eminent, are human and can make mistakes.

segment.tip: 在个别情况下，正义不再是一种抽象概念。
segment.a: There are rare instances when justice almost ceases to be an abstract concept.

segment.tip: 奖惩的实施是不受人意志支配的。
segment.a: Reward or punishment are meted out quite independent of human interference.

segment.tip: 在这种时候，正义像一种有生命的力量行使其职能。
segment.a: At such times, justice acts like a living force.

segment.tip: 当我们说“他罪有应得”这句话的时候，我们部分承认了某种特定的环境使得正义自动地起了作用。
segment.a: When we use a phrase like 'it serves him right', we are, in part, admitting that a certain set of circumstances has enabled justice to act of its own accord.

segment.tip: 一天上午，当一个小偷在一家大型珠宝店里被人抓住的时候，店员一定会忍不住说：“他罪有应得。”
segment.a: When a thief was caught on the premises of large jewellery store on morning, the shop assistants must have found it impossible to resist the temptation to say 'it serves him right.'

segment.tip: 那是一座老式的、经过改造的房子，店里有许多废置不用的大壁炉和又高又窄的烟囱。
segment.a: The shop was an old converted house with many large, disused fireplaces and tall, narrow chimneys.

segment.tip: 快到中午的时候，一个女售货员听见从一堵墙里传出一种闷声闷气的叫声。
segment.a: Towards midday, a girl heard a muffed cry coming from behind on of the walls.

segment.tip: 由于这种喊叫声重复了几次，她跑去报告经理，经理当即给消防队挂了电话。
segment.a: As the cry was repeated several times, she ran to tell the manager who promptly rang up the fire brigade.

segment.tip: 喊叫声肯定是从烟囱里传出来的，然而，因为烟囱太多，消防队员无法确定到底是哪一个。
segment.a: The cry had certainly come form one of the chimneys, but as there were so many of them, the fire fighters could not be certain which one it was.

segment.tip: 他们通过叫击烟囱倾叫声而确定传出声音的那个烟囱。
segment.a: They located the right chimney by tapping at the walls and listening for the man's cries.

segment.tip: 他们凿透了18英寸厚的墙壁，发现有个人卡在烟囱里。
segment.a: After chipping through a wall which was eighteen inches thick, they found that a man had been trapped in the chimney.

segment.tip: 由于烟囱太窄，那人无法动弹。消防队员在墙上挖了个大洞，才终于把他解救出来。
segment.a: As it was extremely narrow, the man was unable to move, but the fire fighters were eventually able to free him by cutting a huge hole in the wall.

segment.tip: 那个看来满脸沮丧、浑身漆黑的家伙从烟囱里一出来，就承认头天夜里他企图到店里行窍，但让烟囱卡住了。
segment.a: The sorry-looking, blackened figure that emerged, admitted at once that he had tried to break into the shop during the night but had got stuck in the chimney.

segment.tip: 他已经在烟囱里被困了将近10个小时。
segment.a: He had been there for nearly ten hours.

segment.tip: 甚至在那人还没被送交给警察之前，正义就已得到了伸张。
segment.a: Justice had been done even before the man was handed over to the police.
